title: Excellent £11.95 lunch
text: A safe environment as far as distancing was concerned. A small, but nicely balanced lunch menu at a standard price of £11.95. The Squash risotto and the Chinese style noodle salad with pork were both great and a good size. Nice service in a very pleasant, relaxed, environment. Our friend, who lives locally said she would definitely be back!

title: Great 'up market' Indian food with great service
text: We took advantage of the Chancellor's 'Eat out to help out' offer and ate here a couple of weeks ago. Safety was well observed, the food was great and the service was first class, very friendly and efficient. Price wise it is about 50% more expensive than a 'standard' Indian restaurant, but offers a much nicer environment and way better service. Be aware that a service charge is added, as a routine. Around £35/head for two courses with a drink making it more of a 'special occasion' venue in our book. We'd go back even at full price!

title: The best place to watch the sun setting over the Petronus Towers
text: A Strange combination of a swimming pool and a bar. The couch areas aren't particularly comfortable but the views from the right-hand side of the pool are just great as the sun goes down over the towers opposite. Moderately expensive, but for that view it was worth it!

title: Nice change from the city
text: After climbing down from the Batu caves there is nothing quite like a soothing paddle in the lake at the bottom of these waterfalls. The locals clearly love the place and splash about happily in the agreeably cool waters. Watch out for the monkeys!

title: Not the best
text: Maybe we didn't see this restaurant at its best, as we were part of a large group having dinner there. The ambience as you walk in, in the evening, is great and the Balinese construction really enticing. The food was fine, but was slow in coming, and there just weren't enough servers to keep our party happy. May be a different experience if you were coming in ones or twos. On this showing, couldn't recommend it.

title: A public hot spring
text: This place isn't designed as a tourist draw, its somewhere the locals go and relax. Well, that is if you can relax in water up to 40 degrees! Experience all of the different temperatures available, but don't immerse yourself in the hotter pools, they are just far too hot. Also try jumping up and down on the pebble shelf pool. That gives your feet a proper pummelling!

title: A long climb
text: If you are into Hindu mythology there is loads to regale you here, a temple to Ganesh and the third largest religious statue in the world to Lord Murugan. You get a bit of exercise climbing up, with the devotees, to the caves beyond the statue and get a great view down. Watch all the monkeys, including their babies in the inner cave. Need to take care on coming down the steps - its a long fall!

title: Banana leaf experience
text: Were taken to Devi's after a hot day travelling around the site. It is what it is, an experience if you've never eaten off a banana leaf before! As much rice, veg and chutney as you can eat with a protein - we shared a squid between the two of us and it was plenty for lunch. The price was just amazing at around £3.50 a head! I guess, they save on the washing up!

title: Great Malaysian food
text: We were a big group and were recommended to come here for a Malaysian treat, and that is precisely what we got. Great food and drinks at a sensible price for a fantastic spread of starters and fish and meat mains. Around 325/head including a generous tip and plenty of beer!

title: Great seafood street food
text: Went with a whole bunch of mates down Alor Street and were impressed by the number of people dining here and the turn over, which is usually a good indication of quality. We weren't disappointed by the fantastic selection of dishes available, which were served rapidly and were absolutely delicious. The stingray was a stand out meal. Absolutely recommend this for the £14/head we paid to fill our boots and without stinting on the beers!

title: Great hotel
text: The Majestic is one of those large hotels that still seems to maintain personality. Everything about it was great, the service, the rooms and the food. Its position makes it a bit difficult to navigate your way around all of the roads that entwine themselves around it, if you are travelling on foot. It is, however, close to the MRT station which is almost certainly the best way of getting into the centre of KL, because the traffic is awful!

title: Tour lunch
text: Just stopped here for the buffet lunch on our way through from the sacred valley. Wise choice of different meats, grilled or casseroled, as well as ceviches and other Peruvian specialities. Self service with charge on top for drinks, although tea and coffee were provided. Small craft market in the square on your way in and out.

title: Delightful lunch, with a lesson in how to make a causa
text: We stopped here for lunch on arriving in the Colca Valley and were taken down to the restaurant. Beautiful views out across the valley and a typical Andean meal; you were provided with all of the ingredients for a causa, mashed portato with lemon, fish and diced veg, and then shown how to make it. This was followed by some delicious barbecued alpaca. A great way to start this part of our trip!

title: Probably better than most
text: One of those places that you are often booked into on your tours of the Colca Valley. Friendly enough, and plenty of meat options in the buffet. Drinks are extra on top of your package meal.

title: Another pit stop on the Colca Canyon tour
text: Average buffet lunch as set up for the tourists. Not really an awful lot else to say. Drinks are on top of what your tour includes.

title: Temple of the sun - its a climb, but it's worth it.
text: This is a great, but physically challenging, site as long as you have a good guide - take one! The climb up to the temple of the sun at the top is something any responsible guide lets you take in bite-sized chunks as even pretty fit individuals can be seen puffing their way up the sometimes precarious steps. However, once you understand the importance of the site as a 'calendar' for the Incas you understand that it was probably even more important than Machu Pichu to their civilisation. Possibly the best ancient site in the Sacred Valley.

title: Stunning and secluded
text: So off the beaten track that you either need someone with local knowledge, or need to know how to get there! There is a £5 car parking charge, payable at the meter before you get to the beach. There is a pretty challenging climb down to the cove, but it is stunning, and secluded, when you do get there! No services, so take everything with you; its part of the charm!

title: You need to know how to book!
text: Manana’s is clearly a bit of an Abersoch institution, having a quirky ‘on-the day’ booking system which favours those who know the ropes. Having said that every time we passed it was packed with lots if happy-looking people. Provides the sort of Central American experience that customers, of all ages, want at a reasonable price and in a very casual environment.

title: Great breakfast
text: A great place for a lazy weekend, or weekday during the season, breakfast with fast, efficient and friendly service. Good to be able to enjoy food or drinks outside if the weather is nice, or inside if it isn’t.

title: You get what you pay for!
text: The Ibis is precisely what it says it is. Set on top of a car park it does, however, provide reasonable accommodation at a very reasonable price. Albeit on the ‘other side’ of the Clyde from the majority of the city, it’s somewhere to flop after a hard day out and about. Breakfast usually included, dependent upon how and what you book.

title: A hidden gem
text: A great place to enjoy a coffee, a drink or something to eat in this upcoming dining area in Altrincham. Signature cocktails, or decent wine are ever available throughout the day and into the evening as well as superb coffee, roasted on the premises. We had a lunch for 2 with coffees, plenty of water and including a tip for £23.95. Very comfortable, relaxing surroundings with very friendly and helpful hosts. A great addition to Altrincham, although on the pricier side.

title: Good value community restaurant
text: We were taken to this community-based restaurant for a midweek lunch. A number of specials were available in addition to the published menu; we enjoyed a great Venison ragu as one of those specials. At around £10 a head, for a single course lunch including water and coffee, this offered good value for money.

title: Ideal place to take kids for the day when the sun is shining
text: With its Hall, extensive gardens and playgrounds, petting zoo, pitch and putt and other attractions this is a great place to bring young and old for a day out on a nice sunny day. Parking is cheap at £3 for the day and there are plenty of food outlets dotted around, although it is invariably cheaper to bring a picnic. Short term attractions will lighten your pocket, yet keep any youngsters expending more energy. A great place.

title: Large portions: Try the feast for 2
text: Had lunch at Comptoir with some friends recently. A really welcome addition to the Manchester City centre, providing really nice middle eastern food, in sizeable portions, and at a very reasonable price. The Feast for 2 is great value. You get 7 or 8 starters and then one mixed grill main, and a vegetarian tagine to share. To be honest the starters would feed four! Around £37/head including half a bottle of wine, water and coffees.

title: A welcoming licenced cafe
text: Had lunch with a friend at the Snap Tin and was very pleasantly surprised by just how busy it was mid-week for lunch. Wide-ranging menu with daily specials, and the ability to have something alcoholic with your meal. Well cooked, nice service in a friendly atmosphere with plenty of parking in the adjacent Civic centre care park. Around £15/head for a main, a pint and a coffee.

title: Great value
text: Some friends invited us to join them at Sokrates for a midweek dinner. The food was great and it was fantastic value; the house wines were really good for the money. The night we went the atmosphere was very slow which, I gather, is not normally the case! definitely somewhere to try again. Around £30/head including half a bottle of wine.

title: Quick walk round with the combined ticket
text: The Acropolis combined ticket gives you access. It's a bit difficult to work out what is what. There is a nice little museum

title: The whole of Greek history in one place
text: Fantastic museum, but like so many all-encompassing sites there is so much to take in your brain begins to fade after a couple of hours. Nice cafe, if a little expensive, in the basement.

title: Great seafood restaurant
text: This was our most expensive meal in Athens, but it was so worth it. Great selection of locally caught fresh fish in some very creative iterations. Lovely, vibrant wines to accompany the dishes and all served in a nice tree-lined avenue in the fresh air. Service was a just bit and miss which is why I downgraded this from 5 stars. We went mid-week; I'm sure you'd have to book at busier times. Go for the food, it's delicious!

title: Possibly our best Greek food in Athens
text: Fab. Great mixed starter. Big portion mains but not overfacing. Swift service. Very pleasant people.€22/head including wine and coffee. Don't sit on the outside edge of the patio otherwise you will be bothered by hawkers and beggars!

title: Great view, but very slow service
text: We went to Diodos mainly as it is reputed to be one of the places to look up the Acropolis as the sun goes down - its great for that. The food was nice but the service was unbelievably slow and not everything on the menu was available on the evening we were there. Around €25/head for a starter/main and a bottle of wine and water.

title: A great place for a pit stop from the heat - oh, and delicious ice-cream!
text: Delicious ice-cream. 3 balls €5.40 berry sorbet is absolutely delicious as was mango sorbet.Sit outside and watch the world go by. Have a coffee or a drink after you've finished your ice-cream.

title: Huge portions
text: Huge portions. 1 main dish would easily feed 2! Around €10 for a main and €5.50 for a Greek salad. Large beers €3.40. Open most of the day and night, often with musicians playing for the assembled guests.

title: Never been anywhere else like this
text: Absolutely brilliant. Go early or book if you can find out how in English. Small, comfy and very special. Share the mixed cold cuts and follow with a main. It’s plenty. Free water, really good wine from €12 a bottle. Excellent, lovely service.

title: Plan when you go, and don't forget the sun screen
text: The Acropolis is one of those must go places, and its well worth the effort. Try to get there earlyish in the morning, ideally when its a bit overcast if you can as the site is very exposed and its very easy to get overdosed with heat and sun, Its an excellent vantage point for some stunning photography and gives you a fantastic appreciation of the city.

title: Go before you climb the Acropolis
text: This remodelled museum is brilliant, although photography isn't allowed in all of the rooms. There is a concessionary rate if you are over 65. It will take you a good half day to do the museum justice and it explains so much about the adjacent Acropolis, that I would suggest its an absolute must before you climb up to the site; you'll understand its history, and relevance, so much more if you do.

title: Slow and very mediocre service
text: Quick Pitta is very central and should do better. It clearly has a loyal takeaway clientele, but offered very slow service, which was very mediocre if you were dining in. It's one of those places that offers a reasonable product at a reasonable price, but you have to wait for it and have it served to you in a pretty uncommitted manner.

title: Straight off the cold plate!
text: Novel take on ice cream. Choose your base ice-cream (vanilla, chocolate, coconut milk), add additions such as chocolate, biscuits, fruit then add in different types of nut and watch it being chopped up, spread and made into rolls on a cold plate. Equivalent to 3 scoops for just over €6. Great fun on a very hot day!

title: Zulaika was the perfect guide
text: A colleague told us about Kampala walking tours. We booked with Zulaika who, despite the rainy weather, managed to get us around all of the important places in Kampala in a couple of hours for $20. She also helped sort out taxis back to the airport, so was an invaluable asset! Thank you.

title: Very reasonable place for dinner by the poolside
text: Once your taxi driver can find the hotel, its great. There are two Marriott's in Kampala so make sure you specify which you want...which we didn't so had a tour of the city during the rush hour! Great views and a reasonable buffet dinner by the pool,
place: Protea Hotel by Marriott Kampala Skyz

title: An oasis!
text: Just loved this hotel. It truly is an oasis in the midst of the turmoil that is Kampala. Great service in very, very comfortable surroundings and good value for such a large international establishment, Right on the site of the large adjacent convention centre, so an absolute must if staying in Kampala.

title: Good, but not great, country house hotel
text: We were treated to a night at Holbeck Ghyll by some friends who were hosting a special birthday there recently. The rooms were very comfortable, although a little dated and ours smelt a bit musty. The service, however, was impeccable and the food, for a large of gathering of >50 people, was exceptional. The hotel stands on a great spot overlooking Windermere and, if the weather allows, offers exceptional views of the lake and the Langdale Pikes.

title: The tasting menu is amazing!
text: If you are into food, and like the enormous variety that can be brought into vegetarian `Indian food then you have to try Prashad. We had been inspired by their first cook book, but wanted to try their food first hand. Alhough it had taken us an age to get around to driving down the M62 to get there it was well worth the wait! We decided to splash out on the 7 course tasting menu, which was an absolute bargain at £50 for the meal, plus whatever you drank. Each course was beautifully presented, as can be seen from the accompanying photos, all so different, and so, so tasty. I would go back in a heartbeat.

title: Great value spot for lunch
text: Who doesn’t love a bargain, well lunch at Syriana is just that. For £10.95 for two courses and a coffee you just can’t go wrong, especially when the starter is a full bowl of salad, or whatever you have chosen, often accompanied at the same time as the main – which is fine. Great place for a relaxed and healthy meal that will set you up for the day. Brilliant!

title: Nice enough museum, but you need a guide
text: The Mohatta Palace is a jewel in Pakistan’s heritage which has been extensively remodelled. It tells the story of the civilisations prior to the formation of the state of Pakistan, and there are guides who will regale you with the relevance of all of the historical sites amalgamated here. Nice peaceful place with loads of history but not up to the standard of many a museum elsewhere in the world.

title: Typical Deli restaurant - safe and tasty
text: This restaurant is clearly very popular with the locals and, at 1,400 covers, has plenty of space to put them. Having said that we were there mid-week early in the evening and it was till pretty full. The food is essentially an aggregation of the middle-eastern foods we know well in the UK with soups, salads such as fattoush and humus and all manner of grilled meats, which you can see being prepared in the ‘open’ kitchens on each floor of this massive edifice. The food is safe and very tasty.

title: A large corporate hotel
text: The Movenpick is a bit of a fortress, like most of the large international hotels in Karachi. Several layers of security and large blast walls around the perimeter. It is a large, fairly soul-less corporate hotel which has a number of restaurants within the safety of its walls; the Chinese one is very reasonable. It is possible to get some alcohol here, but you have to go up to the cigar lounge on the 9th floor to avail yourself of a limited number of drink options.

title: Good insight into Thai beliefs
text: This ‘market’, a mass of stalls selling good luck charms that are of significant interest to the locals and probably of little interest to most non-Thais, The market spreads from the area around Pier 9 back to the Maharajah pier shopping complex. It is more than a bit of a rabbit warren and if there is something you think you like the look of I would recommend you buy it, as its unlikely that you’ll be able to find that stall again! Having said all of this there are some nice things to be bought in the area, including this stamped metal plaque of Buddha which costs us ฿200 (£5.50).

title: Good introduction to Thai culture - wear slip on shoes!
text: A great primer of Thai culture – mostly air conditioned so a good place to go in the middle of the day. Great collections and well explained exhibits in a number of old Royal buildings. You need to remove your shoes a lot because you are either entering religious places or into somewhere with wooden floors, so slip on shoes are to be preferred. The Front Palace museum and the Funeral Chariot garages were our favourite places amongst the teens of different areas, but if your brain can cope with it you could spend all day here!

title: Solid Gold experience
text: This large temple, right behind the main Chinatown gate at the start of Yaorawat Road, boasts the largest solid gold Buddha in the world. It will cost you ฿40 to go and see it and a bit more if you want to explore the museum. The statue itself is a fascinating colour dependent upon the daylight, which comes in from three different aspects. Worth every penny to go and see (the museum was closed when we went).
place: Temple of the Golden Buddha (Wat Traimit)

title: Good as a temple at Sunset!
text: Probably best seen as part of a guided tour. Is across the Chao Phraya from the Palace and the majority of the famous temple complexes and is a good place to finish your tour. Beautiful decorative porcelain work. Quite steep, so is quite arduous at the end of a long afternoon temple hopping. Pier 8 will receive boats to drop you and take you back from the Wat.

title: Impressive size
text: Probably best seen as part of a guided tour. This is a truely massive Buddha. Make sure you make it all the way around otherwise you'll miss the inscriptions on the feet!
place: Bangkok Reclining Buddha (Wat Pho) Entrance Ticket

title: Great place to commune with Buddha
text: Again probably best seen as part of a guided tour. The Ramayana is expertly painted, and in very good condition, in over 170 panels in a cloistered walkway; you either need to know the story or have it explained to you. There is loads of Hindu mythology in this area, which all surrounds the magnificent golden 'bot' that dominates the vicinity. The decoration on the surrounding buildings is stunning. Sit under the Bodhi tree, or look at the water lilies, and be absorbed by the Buddhist experience. The biggest disappointment is that you can't photograph the jade Buddha. Aw well!!
place: Temple of the Emerald Buddha (Wat Phra Kaew)

title: The things around it are better
text: Probably best seen as part of a guided tour, otherwise seeing the various components in the right order, and with the right context will be difficult to achieve. We did our tour with Edo from Get your Guide tours; he was great even though his English was a little stilted. This was, however, quite an expensive tour (but included entry to the Palace, Wat Phra Kaeo, Wat Pho and Wat Arun as well as transportation and all entry fees), and is quite an endurance, lasting four and a half hours – water is provided, but you need sunscreen, sunglasses and a hat as well as your camera and, preferably, slip off shoes as you’ll be going in a lot of temples (Edo is an excellent photographer!). The grand Palace really can’t be seen without traversing the palace walls and you will see the outer aspects of the building; not the Royal Family’s apartments.It naturally leads on to Eat Phra Kaeo.

title: Buyer beware, especially the rides there and back!
text: It’s safe but there are plenty of people trying to entice you into the seedier side of Bangkok’s night life or take advantage of you if you let them – buyer beware. It’s also advisable to be conscious of the security of your valuables as there are loads of people, and every opportunity, to get your pockets picked. Virtually nothing that’s up for sale is the genuine article, and certainly not at the price you are first quoted, or even after a fair bit of haggling! Probably the biggest sharks are the tuk tuk and cab drivers dropping you there, who inflate the price tremendously once you reach the destination or take you away from it.

title: Good, all round ramen joint
text: This seemingly inauspicious Japanese restaurant just down from Patpong market offers good rice and noodle dishes and has some specialities such as its Volcano Tonkotsu cooked in a granite bowl, which produces an effective ‘eruption’ when broth is poured into the magma chamber! At ฿950 (£13/head) for two large combination main meals (a main plus a side) and beers it was good value. It also offers beer tubes – 3L of Asahi for ฿800 – if you’re in a big group.

title: Comfortable and safe
text: ฿1,100 for 4 tapas style starters, and a salad, plus drinks. Nice, air-conditioned café just around the corner from the Sheraton hotel. Wide range of snacks and larger meals, and plenty of choice of things to drink. Not the cheapest in the world but comfortable, safe and good quality food.

title: Great concierge
text: The Royal Orchid Sheraton has comfortable rooms, most of which look out on the Chao Phraya and over to Longsan Plaza and Iconsiam. You can get the free Iconsiam, or hotel, shuttle across to the plaza. It is also very handy for the expressboat which, at ฿15/head each way, will get you up the orange line to the old-city stop at Tha Chang (Pier 9) for the Grand Palace, Wat Phra Kaeo, Wat Pho and the National Museum or Pier 8 for Wat Arun. The breakfasts are great and we had exemplary service from the concierge, especially Boonmee Tangwong and his collegaues, who both guided us and organised our return taxi to Suvarnabhumi for ฿500 (around £14); this included the toll surcharge. Nice hotel with great WiFi but could be a bit noisy at night from its convention centre’s function rooms.

title: If you are into Hinduism you must go
text: Like all Hindu temples this is incredibly welcoming and, if you are lucky, there is a pooja going on whilst you are there. The artwork is sublime - don't miss Nandi residing on the wall! Its a temple predominately devoted to Kali, so she is depicted in a number of different guises. Don't miss the wonderful Nataraja on the right hand wall on your way out. Modesty garments are available but beware the astroturf at the shoe changing area if you are wearing socks and its rained. The astroturf absorbs a lot of water and can make your feet very soggy for the journey back to where you are staying!!

title: A welcome respite from the bustle of little India!
text: We just wanted somewhere cool for a drink and happened across the banana leaf Apolo. Got a great mango lassi for $3.50 which we were able to enjoy in air-conditioned luxury! there aren't many places that offered a cool drink and a seat in the area so this oasis was an absolute delight. Would be ver tempted to go back.

title: Cosmopolitan and more organised than little India.
text: The whole area of Kampong Glam radiates out from the Sultan Mosque. It is a short walk from Bugis and provides a different shopping experience from many other places in Singapore, with local food/spice/carpets and textiles all for sale. Nice if you haven't seen this in a thousand other places around the world, but a much more homely iteration of the old city than many other places portray. It is certainly a lot more user friendly than little India, which is true to its home country roots!

title: Welcoming
text: This mosque has beautiful exterior but like most mosques its interior is much less flamboyant. Having said that the gentleman helping people with additional garments to maintain respectful modesty was very helpful and the small exhibition about Islam the religion, its meaning and its customs was really good and well worth going in for. A nice visit if you are interested in religious inclusivity.

title: See the free exhibits first and decide whether you want to see more
text: The artefacts in exhibit areas 1 and 2 give a pretty good appreciation of Singapores history, and are great places to avoid the midday heat. If you ant more it is probably better to get a guide and pay the entry fee for the old museum which explains things in greater detail. There is a concession fee of $4/head for the over 60s.

title: Iconic, but you'll do a lot of walking with little shade
text: Everyone who visits Singapore wants a picture of Marina Bay Sands and this is the place to get that shot. However, there is little shade against the hot Singaporean sunshine and you need comfy shoes to get you around all of the construction works that are going on. You'll need to get that shot, but the malls are all very much the same and the food courts packed.

title: You pay for where it is!
text: The fennel cafe is nicely placed at the end of the flowerdome and is one of relatively few eating opportunities there. We paid $28 for 2 'Italian sodas', soda water with a syrup. Very tasty but, at £8 a glass, they must be having a laugh!. Go well prepared and save yourself a fortune!

title: Crowded!
text: The gardens outside are for free, including the Forest grove but you have to pay for the flower dome ($23, or $28 for dome and cloud forest). Plenty of restful places in the gardens, but a fair way from the Bayfront MRT, so you'll get a fair bit of exercise! The flower dome was a lot of a scrum when we were there, especially if you try and work your way around the masses of tourists wanting to spend ages taking pictures of their nearest and dearest in specific locations. There is a lot to see here if you have an interest in horticulture.

title: A great way to get around - think before you buy the day cards
text: We elected to get to our hotel from Changi airport by the MRT. It was bargain at $2.70 each from Terminal 2 to Bugis, changing at Tanah Merah; whichever terminal you arrive at there is a 'bus to the MRT'. I had read about the day cards but, to be honest if you are in a fairly central location you will walk a fair bit - we have spent around $12 over 3 days and the cheapest card for that period is $20 plus the $10 deposit for the NFC card (which is refundable). You can refill the card you get with your first journey and start getting discounts after 3 and 6 journeys, so unless you are going to be making a lot of journeys to the periphery of the system I'd think really hard before buying a mass transit ticket.

title: Ideally placed
text: Described as an ‘Ultra-chic Boutique hotel’ – just can’t argue with that, it was fabulous. In a perfect central location adjacent to the Bugis MRT ($2.70 from Changi airport with a change across the platform at the same level at Tanah Merah) and all of the local shops. There are plenty of places to eat near by. It has a slightly strange conformation with the reception on the 2nd floor of the Duo tower block, with lifts up to the 25th floor for the communal areas, pool, bars and restaurants. A separate keycard activated lift then takes guests up to the floor their room is on. Brilliant rooms, comfortable bed with great WiFi and AC; ours had a fantastic city view looking down towards Marina Bay and across town. There is a bar, Mr. Stork, and observation deck on the 39th floor which affords great views of the whole of Singapore. The staff are very efficient and those in the restaurants are super helpful. Remon looked after us one night when we decided to take advantage of a special offer in the Alley on 25 – we had a really great evening overlooking the city as it got dark; thanks Remon! The bar is also a great place to enjoy a Singapore sling as the sun goes down. Would definitely return!

title: Comfortable, peaceful hotel
text: Had two days at Marangu. It was comfortable, quiet and peaceful. The rooms were nice and well maintained and the grounds and swimming pool were delightful with plenty of flowers and bird life. An excellent base for exploring the locality, including trekking Kilimanjaro. Very helpful owner, who will arrange guides, and taxis, for you. Nice dinners, which were included in the room price. Not somewhere to come if you want uninterrupted WiFi access, but then that isn't why most people are here!

title: Friendly hotel
text: Went here for a formal dinner. Nice bar and verandah area. Very reasonable buffet meal and not too expensive – Kilimanjaro beer 3,000 shillings a bottle. Nice gift shop which, again, was very reasonable; a good place to stock up on African artefacts before continuing your journey.

title: Take your time - slow service
text: Nice place for dinner even if the weather is wet; it was absolutely pouring whilst we were there. Covered dining area open to the elements, so you need long sleeves and mosquito repellant. The Mimosa big platters are precisely what they say, full of skewers, bits of meat, veg, chips etc etc. With a few beers £15/head. Takes a while for food to come, so bear this in mind if you’re after a meal in a hurry!

title: Yes this an Indian restaurant!
text: An Indian restaurant with a Mexican name in the middle of Tanzania, it doesn’t seem right! Apparently it offered the American food option initially, but it didn’t sell so they switched to Indian, which did. The name stuck. Great food in nice ‘garden’ surroundings and all at a reasonable price. Buffet meal of some starters. 3 or 4 mains, rice, roti and a few beers about £10/head. Don’t forget the mosquito repellant!

title: An institution, but alcohol free!
text: This Moshi traveller institution is just off Market street. It looks like a colonial verandah’d throwback, but offers all variations of great coffee, both hot and cold as well as food and other beverages but not alcohol. Buy your coffee beans here to take home, their house roast, for around $10/kilo and visit the souvenir shop next door which is full of high quality goods.

title: Safe, secure and friendly hotel
text: Nice small hotel with a swimming pool on a quiet road out of the centre of Moshi. Safe, secure and clean with running hot water, effective ac, I damaged fly screens and flushing toilets. The staff are delightful and can’t do enough to help; Yahiya was omnipresent and Grace’s laugh was infectious. A great place to spend time in the shadow of Kilimanjaro.

title: Nice views of the Sacred Valley - look out for the giant hummingbirds
text: These terraces at the top end of the Sacred Valley are very impressive by virtue of their size, but also because their elevation provides you with one of the most fantastic views down the Valley and over Pisac. Although this site is very old, and it emphasises the way in which water conservation/usage was used to allow agriculture at altitude, it really doesn’t add an awful lot to any itinerary if you have seen Machu Pichu. If you are lucky, however, you may catch a sight of the giant Patagonian hummingbirds that are around the area.

title: Beware of what you are buying!
text: Completely set up for the tourists. Beware that much of what is on sale is probably manufactured in China, yet looks like it is made locally.

title: Great location but inadequate check in facilities
text: I was booked in here for just one night to attend a conference. Pretty standard hotel but in a great location if you have to be in or around the Euston/Fitzrovia area. Slowish bar service and very slow check out with only a couple of desks open at full stretch in very limited foyer.

title: Lovely pastas, mediocre sauces and fixed tip
text: Having read glowing reviews of Bancone so, on a recent trip to London, I met a friend there for lunch. Lovely open kitchen dining experience in a tight space, with nice service and sensible wine list. Reasonable choice of starters and mains, all of which are on the smallish side, but are reasonably priced so you can always trade up by having another dish.... The choice of pastas was great, and the underlying stars were well made and cooked perfectly. Although the ragus, sugos, sauces were nice, to my taste there just wasn't enough of them to wow you into submission, hence my rating. Having said that the silk handkerchieves with walnut butter and confit egg yolk was the exception...this was delicious, but eat it as soon as it arrives! Don't be lulled into adding a tip no matter how good the service, as 12.5% is already on your bill!

title: A curate's egg
text: We had a fixed menu dinner with a large group recently and really enjoyed the space and the service we received. Some parts of the menu were absolutely fantastic, the lamb chops were brilliant, but others, the desert were woeful. Would certainly go back again to see how things are progressing, maybe this time for an a la carte experience with just a few friends.

title: Excellent value for a tasting menu
text: Visited at a lunchtime, so getting six courses pretty snappily was not a problem. The food was great, and the servers were extremely helpful and attentive. Having something new to look forward to every six weeks for £29/head, excluding drinks, (around £50/head with a water and a half bottle of wine each) is just such a great concept. Fine dining on a budget!
